tgt_text.5853: As you are no less acquainted with the political laws of your country (which include the customs and usages of the senate) than with the civil, I am particularly desirous to have your opinion whether I was mistaken in an affair which lately came before the house, or not.
tgt_text.5854: This I request, not with a view of being directed in my judgment as to what is passed (for that is now too late), but in order to know how to act in any possible future case of the kind.
tgt_text.5855: You will, ask, perhaps, "Why do you apply for information concerning a point on which you ought to be well instructed ?"
tgt_text.5856: Because the tyranny of former reigns,1 as it introduced a neglect and ignorance of all other parts of useful knowledge, so par­ ticularly of what relates to the customs of the senate;
tgt_text.5857: for who is there so tamely industrious as to desire to learn what he can never have an opportunity of putting in practice?
tgt_text.5858: Besides, it is not very easy to retain even the knowledge one has acquired where no opportunity of employing it occurs.
tgt_text.5859: Hence it was that Liberty, on her return' found us totally ignorant and inexperienced;
tgt_text.5860: and thus in the warmth of our eagerness to taste her sweets, we are sometimes hur­ ried on to action, ere we are well instructed how we ought to act.
tgt_text.5861: But by the institution of our ancestors, it was wisely provided that the young should learn from the old, not only by precept, but by their own observation, how to behave in that sphere in which they were one day themselves to move;
tgt_text.5862: while these, again, in their turn, transmitted the same mode of instruction to their children.
tgt_text.5863: Upon this principle it was that the youth were sent early into the army, that by being taught to obey they might learn to command, and, whilst they followed others, might be trained by degrees to become leaders themselves.
tgt_text.5864: On the same principle, when they were candidates for any office, they were obliged to stand at the door of the senate-house, and were spectators of the public council before they became members of it.
tgt_text.5865: The father of each youth was his instructor upon these occasions, or if he had none, some person of years and dignity supplied the place of a father.
tgt_text.5866: Thus they were taught by that surest method of discipline, Example;

tgt_text.5872: how to make necessary distinctions between contrary opin­ ions, and how to improve upon a former motion:

tgt_text.5874: As for myself, it is true indeed, I served in the army when I was a youth;
tgt_text.5875: but it was at a time when courage was suspected, and want of spirit rewarded;

tgt_text.5877: when there was neither discipline nor obedience, but all was riot, disorder, and confusion;
tgt_text.5878: in short, when it was happier to forget than to remember what one learnt.

tgt_text.5892: The enquiry then before the house was concerning the freedmen of Afranius Dexter, who be­ ing found murdered, it was uncertain whether he fell by his own hands, or by those of his household;

tgt_text.5894: After they had been put to the question, a certain senator (it is of no importance to mention his name, but if you are desirous to know, it was myself) was for acquit­ ting them;

tgt_text.5897: These several opinions were so extremely different that it was impossible either of them could stand with the other.
tgt_text.5898: For what have death and banishment in common with one another?
tgt_text.5899: Why, no more than banishment and acquittal have together.
tgt_text.5900: Though an acquittal approaches rather nearer a sentence of exile than a sentence of death does:

tgt_text.5902: In the meanwhile, those senators who were for punishing with death, and those who proposed banishment, sate together on the same side of the house:

tgt_text.5904: I moved, therefore, that the votes for each of the three opinions should be separately taken, and that two of them should not, under favour of a short truce between themselves, join against the third?
tgt_text.5905: I insisted that such of the members who were for capital punishment should divide from the others who voted for banishment;
tgt_text.5906: and that these two distinct parties should not be permitted to form themselves into a body, in opposition to those who declared for acquittal, when they would immedi­ ately after disunite again:
tgt_text.5907: for it was not material that they agreed in disliking one proposal, since they differed with re­ spect to the other two.
tgt_text.5908: It seemed very extraordinary that he who moved the freedmen should be banished, and the slaves suffer death, should not be allowed to join these two in one motion, but that each question should be ordered to be put to the house separately;
tgt_text.5909: and yet that the votes of one who was for inflicting capital punishment upon the freedmen should be taken together with that of one who was for banishing them.
tgt_text.5910: For if, in the former instance, it was reasonable that the motion should be divided, because it comprehended two distinct propositions, I could not see why, in the latter case, suffrages so extremely different should be thrown into the same scale.
tgt_text.5911: Permit me, then, notwithstanding the point is already settled, to go over it again as if it were still unde­ cided, and to lay before you those reasons at my ease, which I offered to the house in the midst of much interruption and clamour.
tgt_text.5912: Let us suppose there had been only three judges appointed to hear this cause, one of whom was of opinion that the parties in question deserved death;
tgt_text.5913: the other that they should only be banished;
tgt_text.5914: and the third that they ought to be acquitted:
tgt_text.5915: should the two former unite their weight to overpower the latter, or should each be separately balanced?
tgt_text.5916: For the first and second are no more compatible than the second and third.
tgt_text.5917: They ought therefore in the same manner to be counted in the senate as contrary opin­ ions, since they were delivered as different ones.
tgt_text.5918: Suppose the same person had moved that they should both have been banished and put to death, could they possibly, in pursuance of this opinion, have suffered both punishments?
tgt_text.5919: Or could it have been looked upon as one consistent motion when it united two such different decisions?
tgt_text.5920: Why then should the same opinion, when delivered by distinct persons, be con­ sidered as one and entire, which would not be deemed so if it were proposed by a single man?

tgt_text.5924: Let us examine this form, and weigh every sentence:
tgt_text.5925: You who are of this opinion:
tgt_text.5926: that is, for instance, you who are for banishment, come on this side;
tgt_text.5927: namely, on the side of him who moved for banishment.
tgt_text.5928: From whence it is clear he cannot remain on this side of those who are for death.
tgt_text.5929: You who are for any other:
tgt_text.5930: observe, the law is not content with barely saying another, but it adds any.
tgt_text.5931: Now can there be a doubt as to whether they who declare for a capital convic­ tion are of any other opinion than those who propose exile!
tgt_text.5932: Go over to the side of him whose opinion you follow:
tgt_text.5933: does not the law seem, as it were, to call, compel, drive over, those who are of different opinions, to contrary sides?
tgt_text.5934: Does not the consul himself point out, not only by this solemn form of words, but by his band and gesture, the place in which every man is to remain, or to which he is to go over? " But," it is objected, " if this separation is made be­ tween those who vote for inflicting death, and those who are on the side of exile, the opinion for acquitting the pris­ oners must necessarily prevail."
tgt_text.5935: But how does that affect the parties who vote ?
tgt_text.5936: Certainly it does not become them to con­ tend by every art, and urge every expediment, that the milder sentence may not take place.
tgt_text.5937: " Still," say they, " those who are for condemning the accused either capitally or to banishment should be first set in opposition to those who are for acquitting them, and afterwards weighed against each other."
tgt_text.5938: Thus, as, in certain public games, some par­ ticular combatant is set apart by lot and kept to engage with the conqueror;
tgt_text.5939: so, it seems, in the senate there is a first and second combat, and of two different opinions, the prevailing one has still a third to contend with.
tgt_text.5941: when any particular opinion is received, do not all the rest fall of course?
tgt_text.5942: Is it reasonable, then, that one should be thrown into the scale merely to weigh down another?
tgt_text.5943: To express my meaning more plainly:
tgt_text.5944: unless the two parties who are respectively for capital punishment and exile im­ mediately separate upon the first division of the house it would be to no purpose afterwards to dissent from those with whom they joined before.
tgt_text.5945: But I am dictating instead of receiving instruction.-
tgt_text.5946: Ten me then whether you think these votes should have been taken separately?
tgt_text.5947: My mo­ tion, it is true, prevailed;
tgt_text.5948: nevertheless I am desirous to know whether you think I ought to have insisted upon this point, or have yielded as that member did who de­ clared for capital punishment?
tgt_text.5949: For convinced, I will not say of the legality, but at least of the equity of my propo­ sal, he receded from his opinion, and went over to the party for exile:
tgt_text.5950: fearing perhaps, if the votes were taken separately (which he saw would be the case), the freed­ men would be acquitted:
tgt_text.5951: for the numbers were far greater on that side than on either of the other two, separately counted.
tgt_text.5952: The consequence was that those who had been influenced by his authority, when they saw themselves forsaken by his going over to the other party, gave up a motion which they found abandoned by the first proposer, and deserted, as it were, with their leader.
tgt_text.5953: Thus the three opinions were re­ solved at length into two;
tgt_text.5954: and of those two, one prevailed, and the other was rejected;
tgt_text.5955: while the third, as it was not powerful enough to conquer both the others, had only to choose to which of the two it would yield.
tgt_text.5956: Farewell.THE sickness lately in my family, which has carried off several of my servants, some of them, too, in the prime of their years, has been a great affliction to me.
tgt_text.5957: I have two consolations, however, which, though by no means equiva­ lent to such a grief, still are consolations.
tgt_text.5958: One is, that as I have always readily manumitted my slaves, their death does not seem altogether immature, if they lived long enough to receive their freedom:
tgt_text.5959: the other, that I have allowed them to make a kind of will,1 which I observe as religiously as if they were legally entitled to that privilege.
tgt_text.5960: I receive and obey their last requests and injunctions as so many authoritative commands, suffering them to dispose of their effects to whom they please;
tgt_text.5961: with this single restriction, that they leave them to some one in my household, for to slaves the house they are in is a kind of state and com­ monwealth, so to speak.
tgt_text.5962: But though I endeavor to ac­ quiesce under these reflections, yet the same tenderness which led me to show them these indulgences weakens and gets the better of me.
tgt_text.5963: However, I would not wish on that account to become harder:
tgt_text.5964: though the generality of the world, I know, look upon losses of this kind in no other view than as a diminution of their property, and fancy, by cherishing such an unfeeling temper, they show a superior fortitude and philosophy.
tgt_text.5965: Their fortitude and philosophy I will not dispute.
tgt_text.5966: But humane, I am sure, they are not;
tgt_text.5967: for it is the very criterion of true manhood to feel those impressions of sorrow which it endeavors to resist, and to admit not to be above the want of consolation.
tgt_text.5968: But perhaps I have de­ tained you too long upon this subject, though not so long as I would.
tgt_text.5969: There is a certain pleasure even in giving vent to one's grief;
tgt_text.5970: especially when we weep on the bosom of a friend who will approve, or, at least, pardon, our tears.
tgt_text.5972: Is the weather with you as rude and boisterous as it is with us?
tgt_text.5973: All here is in tempest and inundation.
tgt_text.5974: The Ti­ ber has swelled its channel, and overflowed its banks far and wide.
tgt_text.5975: Though the wise precaution of the emperor had guarded against this evil, by cutting several outlets to the river, it has nevertheless flooded all the fields and valleys and entirely overspread the whole face of the flat country.
tgt_text.5976: It seems to have gone out to meet those rivers which it used to receive and carry off in one united stream, and has driven them back to deluge those countries it could not reach itself.
tgt_text.5977: That most delightful of rivers, the Anio, which seems invited and detained in its course by the villas built along its banks, has almost entirely rooted up and carried away the woods which shaded its borders.
tgt_text.5978: It has overthrown whole mountains, and, in endeavouring to find a passage through the mass of ruins that obstructed its way, has forced down houses, and risen and spread over the de­ solation it has occasioned.
tgt_text.5979: The inhabitants of the hill COWl­ tries, who are situated above the reach of this inundation, have been the melancholy spectators of its dreadful effects, having seen costly furniture, instruments of husbandry, ploughs, and oxen with their drivers, whole herds of cattle, together with the trunks of trees, and beams of the neigh­ bouring villas, floating about in different parts.
tgt_text.5980: Nor indeed have these higher places themselves, to which the waters could not reach up, escaped the calamity.
tgt_text.5981: A continued heavy rain and tempestuous hurricane, as destructive as the river itself, poured down upon them, and has destroyed all the enclosures which divided that fertile country.
tgt_text.5982: It has damaged likewise, and even overturned, some of the public buildings, by the fall of which great numbers have been maimed, smothered, bruised.
tgt_text.5983: And thus lamentation over the fate of friends has been added to losses.
tgt_text.5984: I am extremely uneasy lest this extensive ruin should have spread to you:
tgt_text.5985: I beg therefore, if it has not, you will immediately relieve my anxiety;
tgt_text.5986: and indeed I desire you would inform me though it should have done so;
tgt_text.5987: for the difference is not great between fearing a danger, and feeling it;
tgt_text.5988: except that the evil one feels has some bounds, whereas one's ap­ prehensions have none.
tgt_text.5989: For we can suffer no more than what actually has happened but we fear all that possibly could happen.
tgt_text.5990: Farewell.THE common notion is certainly quite a false one, that a man's will is a kind of mirror in which we may clearly discern his real character, for Domitius Tullus appears a much better man since his death than he did during his lifetime.
tgt_text.5991: After having artfully encouraged the expectations of those who paid court to him, with a view to being his heirs, he has left his estate to his niece whom he adopted.
tgt_text.5992: He has given likewise several very considerable legacies among his grandchildren, and also to his great-grandson.
tgt_text.5993: In a word, he has shown himself a most kind relation throughout his whole will;
tgt_text.5994: which is so much the more to be admired as it was not expected of him.
tgt_text.5995: This affair has been very much talked about, and various opinions ex­ pressed:
tgt_text.5996: some call him false, ungrateful, and forgetful, and, while thus railing at him in this way as if they were actually disinherited kindred, betray their own dishonest designs:
tgt_text.5997: others, on the contrary, applaud him extremely for having disappointed the hopes of this infamous tribe of men, whom, considering the disposition of the times, it is but prudence to deceive.
tgt_text.5998: They add that he was not at liberty to make any other will, and that he cannot so properly be said to have bequeathed, as returned, his estate to his adopted daughter, since it was by her means it came to him.
tgt_text.5999: For Curtilius Mancia, whose daughter Domitius Lucanus, brother to this Tullus, married, having taken a dislike to his son-in-law, made this young lady (who was the issue of that marriage) his heiress, upon condition that Lucanus her father would emancipate her.
tgt_text.6000: He accordingly did so, but she being after­ wards adopted by Tullus, her uncle, the design of Mancia's will was entirely frustrated.
tgt_text.6001: For these two brothers having never divided their patrimony, but living together as joint- tenants of one common estate, the daughter of Lucanus, not­ withstanding the act of emancipation, returned back again, together with her large fortune, under the dominion of her father, by means of this fraudulent adoption.
tgt_text.6002: It seems in­ deed to have been the fate of these two brothers to be en­ riched by those who had the greatest aversion to them.
tgt_text.6003: For Domitius Afer, by whom they were adopted, left a will in their favour, which he had made eighteen years before his death;
tgt_text.6004: though it was plain he had since altered his opinion with regard to the family, because he was instrumental in procuring the confiscation of their father's estate.
tgt_text.6005: There is something extremely singular in the resentment of Afer, and the good fortune of the other two;
tgt_text.6006: as it was very extraordi­ nary, on the one hand, that Domitius should endeavour to extirpate from the privileges of society a man whose chil­ dren he had adopted, and, on the other, that these brothers should find a parent in the very person that ruined their father.
tgt_text.6007: But Tullus acted justly, after having been appointed sole heir by his brother, in prejudice to his own daughter, to make her amends by transferring to her this estate, which came to him from Afer, as well as all the rest which he had gained in partnership with his brother.
tgt_text.6008: His will there­ fore deserves the higher praise, having been dictated by nature, justice, and sense of honour;
tgt_text.6009: in which he has returned his obligations to his several relations, according to their respective good offices towards him, not forgetting his wife, having bequeathed to that excellent woman, who patiently endured much for his sake, several delightful villas, besides a large sum of money.
tgt_text.6010: And indeed she de­ served so much the more at his hands, in proportion to the displeasure she incurred on her marriage with him.
tgt_text.6011: It was thought unworthy a person of her birth and repute, so long left a widow by her former husband, by whom she had issue, to marry, in the decline of her life, an old man, merely for his wealth, and who was so sickly and infirm that, even had he passed the best years of his youth and health with her, she might well have been heartily tired of him.
tgt_text.6012: He had so entirely lost the use of all his limbs that he could not move himself in bed without assistance;
tgt_text.6013: and the only enjoy­ ment he had of his riches was to contemplate them.
tgt_text.6014: He was even (sad and disgusting to relate) reduced to the necessity of having his teeth washed and scrubbed by others:
tgt_text.6015: in allusion to which he used frequently to say, when he was complaining of the indignities which his infirmities obliged him to suffer, that he was every day compelled to lick his servant's fingers.
tgt_text.6016: Still, however, he lived on, and was will­ ing to accept of life upon such terms.
tgt_text.6017: That he lived so long as he did was particularly owing, indeed, to the care of his wife, who, whatever reputation she might lose at first by her marriage, acquired great honour by her unwearied devotion as his wife.-
tgt_text.6018: Thus I have given you all the news of the town, where nothing is talked of but Tullus.
tgt_text.6019: It is expected his curiosities will shortly be sold by auction.
tgt_text.6020: He had such an abundant collection of very old statues that he actually filled an extensive garden with them, the very same day he purchased it;
tgt_text.6021: not to mention numberless other antiques, lying neglected in his lumber-room.
tgt_text.6022: If you have anything worth telling me in return, I hope you will not refuse the trouble of writing to me:
tgt_text.6023: not only as we are all of us natu­ rally fond, you know, of news, but because example has a very beneficial influence upon our own conduct.
tgt_text.6025: THOSE works of art or nature which are usually the motives of our travels are often overlooked and neglected if they lie within our reach:
tgt_text.6026: whether it be that we are nat­ urally less inquisitive concerning those things which are near us, while our curiosity is excited by remote objects;
tgt_text.6027: or because the easiness of gratifying a desire is always sure to damp it;
tgt_text.6028: or, perhaps, that we put off from time to time going and seeing what we know we have an opportunity of seeing when we please.
tgt_text.6029: Whatever the reason be, it is certain there are numberless curiosities in and near Rome which we have not only never seen, but even never so much as heard of:
tgt_text.6030: and yet had they been the produce of Greece, or Egypt, or Asia, or any other country which we admire as fertile and pro­ ductive of belief in wonders, we should long since have heard of them, read of them, and enquired into them.
tgt_text.6031: For myself at least, I confess, I have lately been entertained with one of these curiosities, to which I was an entire stranger before.
tgt_text.6032: My wife's grandfather desired I would look over his estate near Ameria.
tgt_text.6034: As I was walking over his grounds, I was shown a lake that lies below them, called Vadimon,2 about which several very extraordinary things are told.
tgt_text.6035: I went up to this lake.
tgt_text.6036: It is perfectly circular in form, like a wheel lying on the ground;
tgt_text.6037: there is not the least curve or projection of the shore, but all is regular, even, and just as if it had been hollowed and cut out by the hand of art.
tgt_text.6038: The water is of a clear sky-blue, though with somewhat of a greenish tinge;
tgt_text.6039: its smell is sulphurous, and its flavour has medicinal properties, and is deemed of great efficacy in all fractures of the limbs, wh.ch it is supposed to heal.
tgt_text.6040: Though of but moderate extent, yet the winds have a great effect upon it, throwing it into violent agitation.
tgt_text.6041: No vessels are suffered to sail here, as its waters are held sacred;
tgt_text.6042: but several float­ ing islands swim about it, covered with reeds and rushes, and with whatever other plants the surrounding marshy ground and the edge itself of the lake produce in greater abundance.
tgt_text.6043: Each island has its peculiar shape and size, but the edges of all of them are worn away by their frequent collision with the shore and one another.
tgt_text.6044: They are all of the same height and motion;
tgt_text.6045: as their respective roots, which are formed like the keel of a boat, may be seen hanging not very far down in the water, and at an equal depth, on whichever side you stand.
tgt_text.6046: Sometimes they move in a cluster, and seem to form one entire little continent;
tgt_text.6047: some­ times they are dispersed into different quarters by the wind;
tgt_text.6048: at other times, when it is calm, they float up and down separately.
tgt_text.6049: You may frequently see one of the larger islands sailing along with a lesser joined to it, like a ship with its long boat;
tgt_text.6050: or, perhaps, seeming to strive which shall out-swim the other:
tgt_text.6051: then again they are all driven to the same spot, and by joining themselves to the shore, sometimes on one side and sometimes on the other, lessen or restore the size of the lake in this part or that, accord­ ingly, till at last uniting in the centre they restore it to its usual size.
tgt_text.6052: The sheep which graze upon the borders of this lake frequently go upon these islands to feed, without per­ ceiving that they have left the shore, until they are alarmed by finding themselves surrounded with water;
tgt_text.6053: as though they had been forcibly conveyed and placed there.
tgt_text.6054: After­ wards, when the wind drives them back again, they as little perceive their return as their departure.
tgt_text.6055: This lake empties itself into a river, which, after running a little way, sinks under ground, and, if anything is thrown in, it brings it up again where the stream emerges.
tgt_text.6056: —I have given you this account because I imagined it would not be less new, nor less agreeable, to you than it was to me;
tgt_text.6057: as I know you take the same pleasure as myself in contemplating the works of nature.
tgt_text.6059: NOTHING, in my opinion, gives a more amiable and be­ coming grace to our studies, as well as manners, than to temper the serious with the gay, lest the former should degenerate into melancholy, and the latter run up into levity.
tgt_text.6060: Upon this plan it is that I diversify my graver works with compositions of a lighter nature.
tgt_text.6061: I had chosen a convenient place and season for some productions of that sort to make their appearance in;
tgt_text.6062: and designing to ac­ custom them early to the tables of the idle, I fixed upon the month of July, which is usually a time of vacation to the courts of justice, in order to read them to some of my friends I had collected together;
tgt_text.6063: and accordingly I placed a desk before each couch.
tgt_text.6064: But as I happened that morning to be unexpectedly called away to attend a cause, I took occasion to preface my recital with an apology.
tgt_text.6065: I entreated my audience not to impute it to me as any want of due regard for the business to which I had invited them that on the very day I had appointed for reading my per­ formances to a small circle of my friends I did not refuse my services to others in their law affairs.
tgt_text.6066: I assured them I would observe the same rule in my writings, and should always give the preference to business, before pleasure;
tgt_text.6067: to serious engagements before amusing ones;
tgt_text.6068: and to my friends before myself.
tgt_text.6069: The poems I recited consisted of a variety of subjects in different metres.
tgt_text.6070: It is thus that we who dare not rely for much upon our abilities endeavour to avoid satiating our readers.
tgt_text.6071: In compliance with the earnest solicitation of my audience, I recited for two days successively;
tgt_text.6072: but not in the manner that several practise, by passing over the feebler passages, and making a merit of so doing:
tgt_text.6073: on the contrary, I omitted nothing, and freely confessed it.
tgt_text.6074: I read the whole, that I might correct the whole;
tgt_text.6075: which it is impossible those who only select particu­ lar passages can do.
tgt_text.6076: The latter method, indeed, may have more the appearance of modesty, and perhaps respect;
tgt_text.6077: but the former shows greater simplicity, as well as a more affec­ tionate disposition towards the audience.
tgt_text.6078: For the belief that a man's friends have so much regard for him as not to be weary on these occasions, is a sure indication of the love he bears them.
tgt_text.6079: Otherwise, what good do friends do you who assemble merely for their own amusement?
tgt_text.6080: He who had rather find his friend's performance correct, than make it so, is to be regarded as a stranger, or one who is too lackadaisical to give himself any trouble.
tgt_text.6081: Your affection for me leaves me no room to doubt that you are impatient to read my book, even in its present very imperfect condi­ tion.
tgt_text.6082: And so you shall, but not until I have made those corrections which were the principal inducement of my recital.
tgt_text.6083: You are already acquainted with some parts of it;
tgt_text.6084: but even those, after they have been improved (or perhaps spoiled, as is sometimes the case by the delay of excessive revision) will seem quite new to you.
tgt_text.6085: For when a piece has undergone various changes, it gets to look new, even in those very parts which remain unaltered.
tgt_text.6087: My affection for you obliges me, not indeed to direct you (for you are far above the want of a guide), but to admonish you carefully to observe and resolutely to put in practice what you already know, that is, in other words, to know it to better purpose.
tgt_text.6088: Consider that you are sent to that noble province, Achaia, the real and genuine Greece, where politeness, learning, and even agriculture itself, are supposed to have taken their first rise;
tgt_text.6089: sent to regulate the condition of free cities;
tgt_text.6090: sent, that is, to a society of men who breathe the spirit of true manhood and liberty;
tgt_text.6091: who Irave maintained the rights they received from Nature, by courage, by virtue, by alliances;
tgt_text.6092: in a word, by civil and religious faith.
tgt_text.6094: their ancient glory, and even that very antiquity itself which, venerable in men, is sacred in states.
tgt_text.6095: Honour them there­ fore for their deeds of old renown, nay, their very legendary traditions.
tgt_text.6096: Grant to every one his full dignity, privileges, yes, and the indulgence of his very vanity.
tgt_text.6097: Remember it was from this nation we derived our laws;
tgt_text.6098: that she did not receive ours by conquest, but gave us hers by favour.
tgt_text.6099: Remember, it is Athens to which you go;
tgt_text.6101: and to deprive such a people of the declining shadow, the remaining name of liberty, would be cruel, in­ human, barbarous.
tgt_text.6102: Physicians, you see, though in sickness there is no difference between freedom and slavery, yet treat persons of the former rank with more tenderness than those of the latter.
tgt_text.6103: Reflect what these cities once were;
tgt_text.6104: but so reflect as not to despise them for what they are now.
tgt_text.6105: Far be pride and asperity from my friend;
tgt_text.6106: nor fear, by a proper condescension, to lay yourself open to contempt.
tgt_text.6107: Can he who is vested with the power and bears the ensigns of authority, can he fail of meeting with respect, unless by pursuing base and sordid measures, and first breaking through that reverence he owes to himself?
tgt_text.6108: Ill, believe me, is power proved by insult;
tgt_text.6109: ill can terror command veneration, and far more effectual is affection in obtaining one's purpose than fear.
tgt_text.6110: For terror operates no longer than its object is present, but love produces its effects with its object at a distance:
tgt_text.6111: and as absence changes the former into hatred, it raises the latter into respect.
tgt_text.6112: And therefore you ought ( and I cannot but repeat it too often), you ought to well consider the nature of your office, and to represent to yourself how great and important the task is of governing a free state.
tgt_text.6113: For what can be better for society than such government, what can be more precious than freedom?
tgt_text.6114: How ignominious then must his conduct be who turns good government into anarchy, and liberty into slavery?
tgt_text.6115: To these considerations let me add, that you have an established reputation to maintain:
tgt_text.6116: the fame you acquired by the administration of the quaestorship in Bithynia,1 the good opinion of the emperor, the credit you obtained when you were tribune and praetor, in a word, this very government, which may be looked upon as the reward of your former services, are all so many glorious weights which are incumbent upon you to support with suitable dignity.
tgt_text.6117: The more strenuously therefore you ought to endeavour that it may not be said you showed greater urbanity, integrity, and ability in a province remote from Rome, than in one which lies so much nearer the capital;
tgt_text.6118: in the midst of a nation of slaves, than among a free peo­ ple;
tgt_text.6119: that it may not be remarked, that it was chance, and not judgment, appointed you to this office;
tgt_text.6120: that your char­ acter was unknown and unexperienced, not tried and ap­ proved.
tgt_text.6121: For (and it is a maxim which your reading and conversation must have often suggested to you) it is a far greater disgrace losing the name one has once acquired than never to have attained it.
tgt_text.6122: I again beg you to be per­ suaded that I did not write this letter with a design of instruction, but of reminder.
tgt_text.6123: Though indeed, if I had, it would have only been in consequence of the great affection I bear you:
tgt_text.6124: a sentiment which I am in no fear of carrying beyond its just bounds:
tgt_text.6125: for there can be no danger of excess where one cannot love too well.
tgt_text.6127: OTHERS may think as they please;
tgt_text.6128: but the happiest man, in my opinion, is he who lives in the conscious anticipa­ tion of an honest and enduring name, and secure of future glory in the eyes of posterity.
tgt_text.6129: I confess, if I had not the reward of an immortal reputation in view, I should prefer a life of uninterrupted ease and indolent retirement to any other.
tgt_text.6130: There seems to be two points worthy every man's attention:
tgt_text.6131: endless fame, or the short duration of life.
tgt_text.6132: Those who are actuated by the former motive ought to exert themselves to the very utmost of their power;
tgt_text.6133: while such as are influenced by the latter should quietly resign themselves to repose, and not wear out a short life in perishable pursuits, as we see so many doing-and then sink at last into utter self-contempt, in the midst of a wretched and fruitless course of false industry.
tgt_text.6134: These are my daily reflections, which I communicate to you, in order to renounce them if you do not agree with them;
tgt_text.6135: as undoubtedly you will, who are for ever meditating some glorious and immortal enterprise.
tgt_text.6136: FarewelLI HAVE spent these several days past, in reading and writing, with the most pleasing tranquillity imaginable.
tgt_text.6137: You will ask, " How that can possibly be in the midst of Rome ? "
tgt_text.6138: It was the time of celebrating the Circensian games;
tgt_text.6139: an entertainment for which I have not the least taste.
tgt_text.6140: They have no novelty, no variety to recommend them, nothing, in short, one would wish to see twice.
tgt_text.6141: It does the more sur­ prise me therefore that so many thousand people should be possessed with the childish passion of desiring so often to see a parcel of horses gallop, and men standing upright in their chariots.
tgt_text.6142: If, indeed, it were the swiftness of the horses, or the skill of the men that attracted them, there might be some pretence of reason for it.
tgt_text.6143: But it is the dress1 they like;
tgt_text.6144: it is the dress that takes their fancy.
tgt_text.6145: And if, in the midst of the course and contest, the different parties were to change colours, their different partisans would change sides, and instantly desert the very same men and horses whom just before they were eagerly following with their eyes, as far as they could see, and shouting out their names with all their might.
tgt_text.6146: Such mighty charms, such wondrous power reside in the colour of a paltry tunic!
tgt_text.6147: And this not only with the common crowd (more con­ temptible than the dress they espouse), but even with serious-thinking people.
tgt_text.6148: When I observe such men thus in­ satiably fond of so silly, so low, so uninteresting, so common an entertainment, I congratulate myself on my indifference to these pleasures:
tgt_text.6149: and am glad to employ the leisure of this season upon my books, which others throw away upon the most idle occupations.
tgt_text.6150: FarewelLI AM pleased to find by your letter that you are engaged in building;
tgt_text.6151: for I may now defend my own conduct by your example.

tgt_text.6395: —You will tell me, perhaps, I have unwarily men­ tioned Aeschines, since Demosthenes is condemned even by him, for running into these figurative expressions.
tgt_text.6396: But observe, I entreat you, how far superior the former orator is to his critic, and superior too in the very passage to which he objects;
tgt_text.6397: for in others, the force of his genius, in those above quoted, its loftiness, makes itself manifest.
tgt_text.6398: But does Aeschines himself avoid those errors which he re­ proves in Demosthenes?
tgt_text.6399: "The oratory says he, "Athen­ ians, and the law, ought to speak the same language;
tgt_text.6400: but when the voice of the law declares one thing, and that of the orator another we should give our vote to the justice of the law, not to the impudence of the orator."
tgt_text.6403: He afterwards manifestly discovered the design he had, of concealing his fraud under cover of the decree, having expressly declared therein that the am­ bassadors sent to the Oretae gave the five talents, not to you, but to Callias.
tgt_text.6404: And that you may be convinced of the truth of what I say (after having stripped the decree of its gallies, its trim, and its arrogant ostentation), read the clause itself."
tgt_text.6406: " Suffer him not to break cover and escape out of the limits of the question."
tgt_text.6407: A metaphor he is so fond of that he repeats it again. "
tgt_text.6408: But remaining firm and confident in the assembly, drive him into the merits of the question, and observe well how he doubles"
tgt_text.6409: -Is his style more reserved and simple when he says:
tgt_text.6410: " But you are ever wounding our ears, and are more con­ cerned in the success of your daily harangues than for the salvation of the city?
tgt_text.6412: —What follows is conceived in a yet higher strain of metaphor:
tgt_text.6413: " Will you not expel this man as the common calamity of Greece?
tgt_text.6414: Will you not seize and punish this pirate of the state, who sails about in quest of favourable conjunctures," &c.—With many other passages of a similar nature.
tgt_text.6415: And now I expect you will make the same attacks upon certain expressions in this letter as you did upon those I have been endeavouring to defend.
tgt_text.6416: The rudder that groans, and the pilot compared to a sea-god, will not, I imagine, escape your criticism:
tgt_text.6417: for I perceive, while I am suing for indulgence to my former style, I have fallen into the same kind of figurative diction which you condemn.
tgt_text.6418: But attack them if you please provided you will immediately appoint a day when we may meet to discuss these matters in person:
tgt_text.6419: you will then either teach me to be less daring or I shall teach you to be more bold.
tgt_text.6421: I HAVE met with a story, which, although authenticated by undoubted evidence, looks very like fable, and would afford a worthy field for the exercise of so exuberant, lofty, and truly poetical a genius as your own.
tgt_text.6422: It was related to me the other day over the dinner table, where the con­ versation happened to run upon various kinds of marvels.
tgt_text.6423: The person who told the story was a man of unsuspected veracity :
tgt_text.6424: -but what has a poet to do with truth?
tgt_text.6425: How­ ever, you might venture to rely upon his testimony, even though you had the character of a faithful historian to support.
tgt_text.6426: There is in Africa a town called Hippo, situated not far from the sea-coast:
tgt_text.6427: it stands upon a navigable lake, communicating with an estuary in the form of a river, which alternately flows into the lake, or into the ocean, according to the ebb and flow of the tide.
tgt_text.6428: People of all ages amuse themselves here with fishing, sailing, or swim­ ming;
tgt_text.6429: especially boys, whom love of play brings to the spot.
tgt_text.6430: With these it is a fine and manly achievement to be able to swim the farthest;
tgt_text.6431: and he that leaves the shore and his companions at the greatest distance gains the victory.
tgt_text.6432: It happened, in one of these trials of skill, that a certain boy, bolder than the rest, launched out towards the opposite shore.
tgt_text.6433: He was met by a dolphin 9 who sometimes swam before him, and sometimes behind him, then played round him, and at last took him upon his back, and set him down, and afterwards took him up again;
tgt_text.6434: and thus he carried the poor frightened fellow out into the deepest part;
tgt_text.6435: when immediately he turns back again to the shore, and lands him among his companions.
tgt_text.6436: The fame of this remarkable accident spread through the town, and crowds of people flocked round the boy (whom they viewed as a kind of prodigy) to ask him questions and hear him relate the story.
tgt_text.6437: The next day the shore was thronged with spectators, all attentively watching the ocean, and (what indeed is almost itself an ocean) the lake.
tgt_text.6438: Meanwhile the boys swam as usual, and among the rest, the boy I am speaking of went into the lake, but with more caution than before.
tgt_text.6439: The dolphin appeared again and came to the boy, who, together with his companions, swam away with the utmost precipita­ tion.
tgt_text.6440: The dolphin, as though to invite and call them back, leaped and dived up and down, in a series of circular move­ ments.
tgt_text.6441: This he practised the next day, the day after, and for several days together, till the people (accustomed from their infancy to the sea) began to be ashamed of their timidity.
tgt_text.6442: They ventured, therefore, to advance nearer, play­ ing with him and calling him to them, while he, in return, suffered himself to be touched and stroked.
tgt_text.6444: The boy, in particular, who first made the experiment, swam by the side of him, and, leaping upon his back, was carried backwards and forwards in that manner, and thought the dolphin knew him and was fond of him, while he too had grown fond of the dolphin.
tgt_text.6445: There seemed, now, indeed, to be no fear on either side, the con­ fidence of the one and tameness of the other mutually in­ creasing ;
tgt_text.6446: the rest of the boys, in the meanwhile, surrounding and encouraging their companion.
tgt_text.6447: It is very remarkable that this dolphin was followed by a second, which seemed only as a spectator and attendant on the former;
tgt_text.6448: for he did not at all submit to the same familiarities as the first, but only escorted him backwards and forwards, as the boys did their comrade.
tgt_text.6449: But what is further surprising, and no less true than what I have already related, is that this dolphin, who thus played with the boys and carried them upon his back, would come upon the shore, dry himself in the sand, and, as soon as he grew warm, roll back into the sea.
tgt_text.6450: It is a fact that Octavius Avitus, deputy governor of the province, actuated by an absurd piece of superstition, poured some ointment1 over him as he lay on the shore:
tgt_text.6451: the novelty and smell of which made him retire into the ocean, and it was not till several days after that he was seen again, when he appeared dull and languid;
tgt_text.6452: however, he recov­ ered his strength and continued his usual playful tricks.
tgt_text.6453: All the magistrates round flocked hither to view this sight, whose arrival, and prolonged stay, was an additional expense, which the slender finances of this little community would ill afford;
tgt_text.6454: besides, the quiet and retirement of the place was utterly destroyed.
tgt_text.6455: It was thought proper, therefore, to remove the occasion of this concourse, by privately killing the poor dolphin.
tgt_text.6456: And now, with what a flow of tenderness will you describe this affecting catastrophe!
tgt_text.6457: 2 and how will your genius adorn and heighten this moving story!
tgt_text.6458: Though, indeed, the subject does not require any fictitious embel­ lishments;
tgt_text.6459: it will be sufficient to describe the actual facts of the case without suppression or diminution.
tgt_text.6460: FarewelLYou want to know how I portion out my day, in my summer villa at Tuscum?
tgt_text.6461: I get up just when I please;
tgt_text.6462: generally about sunrise, often earlier, but seldom later than this.
tgt_text.6463: I keep the shutters closed, as darkness and silence wonderfully promote meditation.
tgt_text.6464: Thus free and abstracted from these outward objects which dissipate attention, I am left to my own thoughts;
tgt_text.6465: nor suffer my mind to wander with my eyes, but keep my eyes in subjection to my mind, which, when they are not distracted by a multiplicity of external objects, see nothing but what the imagination represents to them.
tgt_text.6466: If I have any work in hand, this is the time I choose for thinking it out, word for word, even to the minutest accuracy of expression.
tgt_text.6467: In this way I com­ pose more or less, according as the subject is more or less difficult, and I find myself able to retain it.
tgt_text.6468: I then call my secretary, and, opening the shutters, dictate to him what 1 have put into shape, after which I dismiss him, then call him in again, and again dismiss him.
tgt_text.6469: About ten or eleven o'clock (for I do not observe one fixed hour), according to the weather, I either walk upon my terrace or in the covered portico, and there I continue to meditate or dictate what remains upon the subject in which I am engaged.
tgt_text.6470: This completed, I get into my chariot, where I employ myself as before, when I was walking, or in my study;
tgt_text.6471: and find this change of scene refreshes and keeps up my attention.
tgt_text.6472: On my return home, I take a little nap, then a walk, and after that repeat out loud and distinctly some Greek or Latin speech, not so much for the sake of strengthening my voice as my digestion;
tgt_text.6473: 1 though indeed the voice at the same time is strengthened by this practice.
tgt_text.6474: I then take another walk, am anointed, do my exercises, and go into the bath.
tgt_text.6475: At supper, if I have only my wife or a few friends with me, some author is read to us;
tgt_text.6476: and after supper we are entertained either with music or an interlude.
tgt_text.6477: When that is finished, I take my walk with my family, among whom I am not without some scholars.
tgt_text.6478: Thus we pass our evenings in varied conversation;
tgt_text.6479: and the day, even when at the longest, steals imperceptibly away.
tgt_text.6480: Upon some occa­ sions I change the order in certain of the articles above- mentioned.
tgt_text.6481: For instance, if I have studied longer or walked more than usual, after my second sleep, and reading a speech or two aloud, instead of using my chariot I get on horseback;
tgt_text.6482: by which means I ensure as much exercise and lose less time.
tgt_text.6483: The visits of my friends from the neigh­ bouring villages claim some part of the day;
tgt_text.6484: and sometimes, by an agreeable interruption, they come in very seasonably to relieve me when I am feeling tired.
tgt_text.6485: I now and then amuse myself with hunting, but always take my tablets into the field, that, if I should meet with no game, I may at least bring home something.
tgt_text.6486: Part of my time too (though not so much as they desire) is allotted to my tenants;
tgt_text.6487: whose rustic complaints, along with these city occupations, make my literary studies still more delightful to me.
tgt_text.6489: As you are not of a disposition to expect from your friends the ordinary ceremonial observances of society when they cannot observe them without inconvenience to them­ selves, so I love you too steadfastly to be apprehensive of your taking otherwise than I wish you should my not wait­ ing upon you on the first day of your entrance upon the consular office, especially as I am detained here by the necessity of letting my farms upon long leases.
tgt_text.6490: I am obliged to enter upon an entirely new plan with my tenants:
tgt_text.6491: for under the former leases, though I made them very con­ siderable abatements, they have run greatly in arrear.
tgt_text.6492: For this reason several of them have not only taken no sort of care to lessen a debt which they found themselves incapable of wholly discharging, but have even seized and consumed all the produce of the land, in the belief that it would now be of no advantage to themselves to spare it.
tgt_text.6493: I must there­ fore obviate this increasing evil, and endeavour to find out some remedy against it.
tgt_text.6494: The only one I can think of is, not to reserve my rent in money, but in kind, and so place some of my servants to overlook the tillage, and guard the stock;
tgt_text.6495: as indeed there is no sort of revenue more agreeable to reason than what arises from the bounty of the soil, the seasons, and the climate.
tgt_text.6496: It is true, this method will require great honesty, sharp eyes, and many hands.
tgt_text.6497: However, I must risk the ex­ periment, and, as in an inveterate complaint, try every change of remedy.
tgt_text.6498: You see, it is not any pleasurable indulgence that prevents my attending you on the first day of your consulship.
tgt_text.6499: I shall celebrate it, nevertheless, as much as if I were present, and pay my vows for you here, with all the warmest tokens of joy and congratulation.
tgt_text.6501: You are much pleased, I find, with the account I gave you in my former letter of how I spend the summer season at Tuscum, and desire to know what alteration I make in my method when I am at Laurentum in the winter.
tgt_text.6502: None at all, except abridging myself of my sleep at noon, and bor­ rowing a good piece of the night before daybreak and after sunset for study:
tgt_text.6503: and if business is very urgent (which in winter very frequently happens), instead of having inter­ ludes or music after supper, I reconsider whatever I have previously dictated, and improve my memory at the same time by this frequent mental revision.
tgt_text.6504: Thus I have given you a general sketch of my mode of life in summer and winter;
tgt_text.6505: to which you may add the intermediate seasons of spring and autumn, in which, while losing nothing out of the day, I gain but little from the night.
tgt_text.6506: Farewell.THE pious affection you bore, most sacred Emperor, to your august father induced you to wish it might be late ere you succeeded him.
tgt_text.6507: But the immortal gods thought proper to hasten the advancement of those virtues to the helm of the commonwealth which had already shared in the steerage.:
tgt_text.6509: May you then, and the world through your means, enjoy every prosperity worthy of your reign:
tgt_text.6510: to which let me add my wishes, most excellent Emperor, upon a private as well as public account, that your health and spirits may be pre­ served firm and unbroken.
tgt_text.6511: You have occasioned me, Sir, an inexpressible pleasure in deeming me worthy of enjoying the privilege which the laws confer on those who have three children.
tgt_text.6512: For al­ though it was from an indulgence to the request of the excellent Julius Servianus, your own most devoted servant, that you granted this favour, yet I have the satisfaction to find by the words of your rescript that you complied the more willingly as his application was in my behalf.
tgt_text.6513: I cannot but look upon myself as in possession of my utmost wish, after having thus received, at the beginning of your most auspicious reign, so distinguishing a mark of your peculiar favour;
tgt_text.6514: at the same time that it considerably heightens my desire of leaving a family behind me.
tgt_text.6515: I was not entirely without this desire even in the late most un­ happy times:
tgt_text.6516: as my two marriages will induce you to be­ lieve..
tgt_text.6517: But the gods decreed it better, by reserving every valuable privilege to the bounty of your generous dispen­ sations.
tgt_text.6518: And indeed the pleasure of being a father will be so much more acceptable to me now, that I can enjoy it in full security and happiness.
tgt_text.6519: THE experience, most excellent Emperor, I have had of your unbounded generosity to me, in my own person, encour­ ages me to hope I may be yet farther obliged to it, in that of my friends.
tgt_text.6520: Voconius Romanus (who was my schoolfellow and companion from our earliest years) claims the first rank in that number;
tgt_text.6521: in consequence of which I petitioned your sacred father to promote him to the dignity of the sena­ torial order.
tgt_text.6522: But the completion of my request is reserved to your goodness;
tgt_text.6523: for his mother had not then advanced, in the manner the law directs, the liberal gift3 of four hundred thousand sesterces, which she engaged to give him, in her letter to the late emperor, your father.
tgt_text.6524: This, however, by my advice she has since done, having made over certain estates to him, as well as completed every other act necessary to make the conveyance valid.
tgt_text.6525: The difficulties therefore being removed which deferred the gratification of our wishes, it is with full confidence I venture to assure you of the worth of my friend Romanus, heightened and adorned as it is not only by liberal culture, but by his extraordinary tender­ ness to his parents as well.
tgt_text.6526: It is to that virtue he owes the present liberality of his mother;
tgt_text.6527: as well as his immediate succession to his late father's estate, and his adoption by his father-in-law.
tgt_text.6528: To these personal qualifications, the wealth and rank of his family give additional lustre;
tgt_text.6529: and I persuade myself it will be some further recommendation that I solicit in his behalf.
tgt_text.6530: Let me, then, entreat you, Sir, to enable me to congratulate Romanus on so desirable an occasion, and at the same time to indulge an eager and, I hope, laudable ambition, of having it in my power to boast that your favourable regards are extended not only to my­ self, but also to my friend.
tgt_text.6531: WHEN by your gracious indulgence, Sir, I was appointed to preside at the treasury of Saturn, I immediately re­ nounced all engagements of the bar ( as indeed I never blended business of that kind with the functions of the state), that no avocations might call off my attention from the post to which I was appointed.
tgt_text.6532: For this reason, when the province of Africa petitioned the senate that I might undertake their cause against Marius Priscus, I excused my­ self from that office;
tgt_text.6534: But when afterwards the consul elect proposed that the senate should apply to us again, and endeavour to prevail with us to yield to its inclinations, and suffer our names to be thrown into the urn, I thought it most agreeable to that tranquillity and good order which so happily distinguishes your times not to oppose (especially in so reasonable an instance) the will of that august assembly.
tgt_text.6535: And, as I am desirous that all my words and actions may receive the sanction of your exemplary virtue, I hope you approve of my compliance.
tgt_text.6536: You acted as became a good citizen and a worthy senator, by paying obedience to the just requisition of that august assembly:
tgt_text.6537: and I have full confidence you will faithfully dis­ charge the business you have undertaken.
tgt_text.6538: HAVING been attacked last year by a very severe and dangerous illness, I employed a physician, whose care and diligence, Sir, I cannot sufficiently reward, but by your gracious assistance.
tgt_text.6539: I entreat you therefore to make him a denizen of Rome;
tgt_text.6540: for as he is the freedman of a foreign lady, he is, consequently, himself also a foreigner.
tgt_text.6542: his patroness (who has been dead a considerable time) was Thermuthis, the daughter of Theon.
tgt_text.6543: I further entreat you to bestow the full privileges of a Roman citizen upon Hedia and Antonia Harmeris, the freedwomen of Antonia Maximilla, a lady of great merit.
tgt_text.6544: It is at her desire I make this request.
tgt_text.6546: Sir, for your ready compliance with my desire, in granting the complete privileges of a Roman to the freedwomen of a lady to whom I am allied and also for making Harpocras, my physician, a denizen of Rome.
tgt_text.6547: But when, agreeably to your directions, I gave in an account of his age, and estate, I was informed by those who are better skilled in the affairs than I pretend to be that, as he is an Egyptian, I ought first to have obtained for him the freedom of Alexandria before he was made free of Rome.
tgt_text.6548: I confess, indeed, as I was ignorant of any difference in this case be­ tween those of Egypt and other countries, I contented my­ self with only acquainting you that he had been manumitted by a foreign lady long since deceased.
tgt_text.6549: However, it is an ignorance I cannot regret, since it affords me an opportunity of receiving from you a double obligation in favour of the same person.
tgt_text.6550: That I may legally therefore enjoy the bene­ fit of your goodness.
tgt_text.6551: I beg you would be pleased to grant him the freedom of the city of Alexandria, as well as that of Rome.
tgt_text.6552: And that your gracious intentions may not meet with any further obstacles, I have taken care, as you directed, to send an account to your freedman of his age and possessions.
tgt_text.6553: IT is my resolution, in pursuance of the maxim observed by the princes my predecessors, to be extremely cautious in granting the freedom of the city of Alexandria:
tgt_text.6554: however, since you have obtained of me the freedom of Rome for your physician Harpocras, I cannot refuse you this other request.
tgt_text.6555: You must let me know to what district he be­ longs, that I may give you a letter to my friend Pompeius Planta, governor of Egypt.
tgt_text.6556: I CANNOT express, Sir, the pleasure your letter gave me, by which I am informed that you have made my physician Harpocras a denizen of Alexandria;
tgt_text.6557: notwithstanding your resolution to follow the maxim of your predecessors in this point, by being extremely cautious in granting that privilege.
tgt_text.6558: Agreeably to your directions, I acquaint you that Harpocras belongs to the district of Memphis.
tgt_text.6559: 1 I entreat you then, most gracious Emperor, to send me, as you promised, a letter to your friend Pompeius Planta, governor of Egypt.
tgt_text.6560: As I purpose (in order to have the earliest enjoyment of your presence, so ardently wished for here) to come to meet you, I beg, Sir, you would permit me to extend my journey as far as possible.
tgt_text.6561: I WAS greatly obliged, Sir, in my late illness, to Post­ humius Marinus, my physician;
tgt_text.6562: and I cannot make him a suitable return, but by the assistance of your wonted gracious indulgence.
tgt_text.6563: I entreat you then to make Chrysippus Mith­ ridates and his wife Stratonica (who are related to Marinus) denizens of Rome.
tgt_text.6564: I entreat likewise the same privilege in favour of Epigonus and Mithridates, the two sons of Chrysippus;
tgt_text.6565: but with this restriction1 that they may remain under the dominion of their father, and yet reserve their right of patronage over their own freedmen.
tgt_text.6566: I further en­ treat you to grant the full privileges of a Roman to L. Satrius Abascantius, P. Caesius Phosphorus, and Pancharia Soteris.
tgt_text.6567: This request I make with the consent of their patrons.
tgt_text.6568: AFTER your late sacred father, Sir, had, in a noble speech, as well as by his own generous example, exhorted and en­ couraged the public to acts of munificence, I implored his permission to remove the several statues which I had of the former emperors to my corporation, and at the same time requested permission to add his own to the number.
tgt_text.6569: For as I had hitherto let them remain in the respective places in which they stood when they were left to me by several different inheritances, they were dispersed in distant parts of my estate.
tgt_text.6570: He was pleased to grant my request, and at the same time to give me a very ample testimony of his ap­ probation.
tgt_text.6571: I immediately, therefore, wrote to the decurii, to desire they would allot a piece of ground, upon which I might build a temple at my own expense;
tgt_text.6572: and they, as a mark of honour to my design, offered me the choice of any site I might think proper.
tgt_text.6573: However, my own ill-health in the first place, and later that of your father, together with the duties of that employment which you were both pleased to entrust me, prevented my proceeding with that design.
tgt_text.6574: But I have now, I think, a convenient opportunity of mak­ ing an excursion for the purpose, as my monthly attendance1 ends on the ist of September, and there are several festivals in the month following.
tgt_text.6575: My first request, then, is that you would permit me to adorn the temple I am going to erect with your statue, and next (in order to the execution of my design with all the expedition possible) that you would in­ dulge me with leave of absence.
tgt_text.6576: It would ill become the sincerity I profess, were I to dissemble that your goodness in complying with this desire will at the same time be ex­ tremely serviceable to me in 'my own private affairs.
tgt_text.6577: It is absolutely necessary I should not defer any longer the let­ ting of my lands in that province;
tgt_text.6578: for, besides that they amount to above four hundred thousand sestei ces,' the time for dressing the vineyards is approaching, and that business must fall upon my new tenants.
tgt_text.6579: The unfruitfulness of the seasons besides, for several years past, obliges me to think of making some abatements in my rents;
tgt_text.6580: which I cannot possibly settle unless I am present.
tgt_text.6581: I shall be indebted then to your indulgence, Sir, for the expedition of my work of piety, and the settlement of my own private affairs, if you will be pleased to grant me leave of absences for thirty days.
tgt_text.6582: I cannot give myself a shorter time, as the town and the estate of which I am speaking lie above a hundred and fifty miles from Rome.
tgt_text.6583: You have given me many private reasons, and every public one, why you desire leave of absence;
tgt_text.6584: but I need no other than that it is your desire:
tgt_text.6585: and I doubt not of your returning as soon as possible to the duty of an office which so much requires your attendance.
tgt_text.6586: As I would not seem to check any instance of your affection towards me, I shall not oppose your erecting my statue in the place you desire;
tgt_text.6587: though in general I am extremely cautious in giving any encourage­ ment to honours of that kind.
tgt_text.6588: As I am sensible, Sir, that the highest applause my actions can receive is to be distinguished by so excellent a prince, I beg you would be graciously pleased to add either the office of augur or septemvir1 (both which are now va­ cant) to the dignity I already enjoy by your indulgence;
tgt_text.6589: that I may have the satisfaction of publicly offering up those vows for your prosperity, from the duty of my office, which I daily prefer to the gods in private, from the affection of my heart.
tgt_text.6590: HAVING safely passed the promontory of Malea, I am ar­ rived at Ephesus with all my retinue, notwithstanding I was detained for some time by contrary winds:
tgt_text.6591: a piece of in­ formation, Sir, in which, I trust, you will feel yourself con­ cerned.
tgt_text.6592: I propose pursuing the remainder of my journey to the province1 partly in light vessels, and partly in post- chaises :
tgt_text.6593: for as the excessive heats will prevent my travelling altogether by land, so the Etesian winds,2 which are now set in, will not permit me to proceed entirely by sea.
tgt_text.6594: YOUR information, my dear Pliny, was extremely agreeable to me, as it does concern me to know in what manner you arrive at your province.
tgt_text.6595: It is a wise intention of yours to travel either by sea or land, as you shall find most convenient.
tgt_text.6596: As I had a very favourable voyage to Ephesus, so in travelling by post-chaise from thence I' was extremely troubled by the heats, and also by some slight feverish at­ tacks, which kept me some time at Pergamus.
tgt_text.6597: From there, Sir, I got on board a coasting vessel, but, being again de­ tained by contrary winds, did not arrive at Bithynia so soon as I had hoped.
tgt_text.6598: However, I have no reason to complain of this delay, since (which indeed was the most auspicious circumstance that could attend me) I reached the province in time to celebrate your birthday.
tgt_text.6599: I am at present engaged in examining the finances of the Prusenses,1 their expenses, revenues, and credits;
tgt_text.6600: and the farther I proceed in this work, the more I am convinced of the necessity of my enquiry.
tgt_text.6601: Several large sums of money are owing to the city from private persons, which they neglect to pay upon various pre­ tences;
tgt_text.6602: as, on the other hand, I find the public funds are, in some instances, very unwarrantably applied.
tgt_text.6604: Sir, I write to you immediately on my arrival.
tgt_text.6605: I entered this province on the 17th of September,2 and found in it that obedience and loyalty towards yourself which you justly merit from all mankind.
tgt_text.6606: You will consider, Sir, whether it would not be proper to send a surveyor here;
tgt_text.6607: for I am in­ clined to think much might be deducted from what is charged by those who have the conduct of the public works if a faithful admeasurement were to be taken:
tgt_text.6608: at least I am of that opinion from what I have already seen of the ac­ counts of this city, which I am now going into as fully as is possible.
tgt_text.6609: I SHOULD have rejoiced to have heard that you arrived at Bithynia without the smallest inconvenience to yourself or any of your retinue, and that your journey from Ephesus had been as easy as your voyage to that place was favourable.
tgt_text.6610: For the rest, your letter informs me, my dearest Secundus, on what day you reached Bithynia.
tgt_text.6611: The people of that province will be convinced, I persuade myself, that I am attentive to their interest;
tgt_text.6612: as your conduct towards them will make it manifest that I could have chosen no more proper person to supply my place.
tgt_text.6613: The examination of the public accounts ought certainly to be your first employment, as they are evidently in great disorder.
tgt_text.6614: I have scarcely sur­ veyors sufficient to inspect those works3 which I am carrying on at Rome, and in the neighbourhood;
tgt_text.6615: but persons of in­ tegrity and skill in this art may be found, most certainly, in every province, so that they will not fail you if only you will make due enquiry.
tgt_text.6616: THOUGH I am well assured, Sir, that you, who never omit any opportunity of exerting your generosity, are not unmindful of the request I lately made to you, yet, as you have often indulged me in this manner, give me leave to remind and earnestly entreat you to bestow the praetorship now vacant upon Attius Sura.
tgt_text.6617: Though his ambition is extremely moderate, yet the quality of his birth, the inflexible integrity he has preserved in a very narrow fortune, and, more than all, the felicity of your times, which encourages conscious virtue to claim your favour, induce him to hope he may experience it in the present instance.
tgt_text.6618: I CONGRATULATE both you and the public, most excellent Emperor, upon the great and glorious victory you have ob­ tained;
tgt_text.6619: so agreeable to the heroism of ancient Rome.
tgt_text.6620: May the immortal gods grant the same happy success to'all your designs, that, under the administration of so many princely virtues, the splendour of the empire may shine out, not only in its former, but with additional lustre.
tgt_text.6622: My lieutenant, Servilius Pudens, came to Nicomedia,1 Sir, on the 24th of November, and by his arrival freed me, at length, from the anxiety of a very uneasy expectation.
tgt_text.6623: YOUR generosity to me, Sir, was the occasion of uniting me to Rosianus Geminus, by the strongest ties;
tgt_text.6624: for he was my quaestor when I was consul.
tgt_text.6625: His behaviour to me during the continuance of our offices was highly respectful, and he has treated me ever since with so peculiar a regard that, besides the many obligations I owe him upon a public account, I am indebted to him for the strongest pledges of private friend­ ship.
tgt_text.6626: I entreat you, then, to comply with my request for the advancement of one whom (if my recommendation has any weight) you will even distinguish with your particular favour;
tgt_text.6627: and whatever trust you shall repose in him, he will endeavour to show himself still deserving of an higher.
tgt_text.6628: But I am the more sparing in my praises of him, being persuaded his integrity, his probity, and his vigilance are well known to you, not only from those high posts which he has exercised in Rome within your immediate inspection, but from his behaviour when he served under you in the army.
tgt_text.6629: One thing, however, my affection for him inclines me to think, I have not yet sufficiently done;
tgt_text.6630: and therefore, Sir, I repeat my entreaties that you will give me the pleasure, as early as possible, of rejoicing in the advancement of my quaestor, or, in other words, of receiving an addition to my own honours, in the person of my friend.
tgt_text.6631: IT is not easy, Sir, to express the joy I received when I heard you had, in compliance with the request of my mother- in-law and myself, granted Coelius Clemens the proconsulship of this province after the expiration of his consular office;
tgt_text.6632: as it is from thence I learn the full extent of your goodness towards me, which thus graciously extends itself through my whole family.
tgt_text.6633: As I dare not pretend to make an equal return to those obligations I so justly owe you, I can only have recourse to vows, and ardently implore the gods that I may not be found unworthy of those favours which you are the repeatedly conferring upon me.
tgt_text.6634: I RECEIVED, Sir, a dispatch from your freedman, Lycor­ mas, desiring me, if any embassy from Bosporus1 should come here on the way to Rome, that I would detain it till his arrival.
tgt_text.6635: None has yet arrived, at least in the city where I now am.
tgt_text.6636: But a courier passing through this place from the king of Sarmatia,3 I embrace the opportunity which ac­ cidentally offers itself, of sending with him the messenger which Lycormas despatched hither, that you might be in­ formed by both their letters of what, perhaps, it may be expedient you should be acquainted with at one and the same time.
tgt_text.6637: I AM informed by a letter from the king of Sarmatia that there are certain affairs of which you ought to be informed as soon as possible.
tgt_text.6638: In order, therefore, to hasten the des­ patches which his courier was charged with to you, I granted him an order to make use of the public post.
tgt_text.6639: 1THE ambassador from the king of Sarmatia having re­ mained two days, by his own choice, at Nicea, I did not think it reasonable, Sir, to detain him any longer:
tgt_text.6640: because, in the first place, it was still uncertain when your freed­ man, Lycormas, would arrive, and then again some indis­ pensable affairs require my presence in a different part of the province.
tgt_text.6641: Of this I thought it necessary that you should be informed, because I lately acquainted you in a letter that Lycormas had desired, if any embassy should come this way from Bosporus, that I would detain it till his arrival.
tgt_text.6642: But I saw no plausible pretext for keeping him back any longer, especially as the despatches from Lycormas, which (as I mentioned before) I was not willing to detain, would prob­ ably reach you some days sooner than this ambassador.
tgt_text.6643: I RECEIVED a letter, Sir, from Apuleius, a military man, belonging to the garrison at Nicomedia, informing me that one Callidromus, being arrested by Maximus and Dionysius (two bakers, to whom he had hired himself), fled for refuge to your statue;
tgt_text.6644: 1 that, being brought before a magistrate, he declared he was formerly slave to Laberius Maximus, but being taken prisoner by Susagus* in Moesia,8 he was sent as a present from Decebalus to Pacorus, king of Parthia, in whose service he continued several years, from whence he made his escape, and came to Nicomedia.
tgt_text.6645: When he was examined before me, he confirmed this account, for which reason I thought it necessary to send4 him to you.
tgt_text.6646: This I should have done sooner, but I delayed his journey in order to make an inquiry concerning a seal ring which he said was taken from him, upon which was engraven the figure of Pacorus in his royal robes;
tgt_text.6647: I was desirous (if it could have been found) of transmitting this curiosity to you, with a small gold nugget which he says he brought from out of the Parthian mines.
tgt_text.6648: I have affixed my seal to it, the impression of which is a chariot drawn by four horses.
tgt_text.6649: YOUR freedman and procurator,6 Maximus, behaved, Sir, during all the time we were together, with great probity, attention, and diligence;
tgt_text.6650: as one strongly attached to your interest, and strictly observant of discipline.
tgt_text.6651: This testi­ mony I willingly give him;
tgt_text.6652: and I give it with all the fidelity I owe you.
tgt_text.6653: AFTER having experienced, Sir, in Gabius Bassus, who commands on the Pontic1 coast, the greatest integrity, honour, and diligence, as well as the most particular re­ spect to myself, I cannot refuse him my best wishes and suffrage;
tgt_text.6654: and I give them to him with all that fidelity which is due to you.
tgt_text.6655: I have found him abundantly qualified by having served in the army under you;
tgt_text.6656: and it is owing to the advantages of your discipline that he has learned to merit your favour.
tgt_text.6657: The soldiery and the people here, who have had full experience of his justice and humanity, rival each other in that glorious testimony they give of his con­ duct, both in public and in private;
tgt_text.6658: and I certify this with all the sincerity you have a right to expect from me.
tgt_text.6659: NYMPHIDIUS Lupus,2 Sir, and myself, served in the army together;
tgt_text.6660: he commanded a body of the auxiliary forces at the same time that I was military tribune;
tgt_text.6661: and it was from thence my affection for him began.
tgt_text.6662: A long acquaintance has since mutually endeared and strengthened our friend­ ship.
tgt_text.6663: For this reason I did violence to his repose, and in­ sisted upon his attending me into Bithynia, as my assessor in council.
tgt_text.6664: He most readily granted me this proof of his friendship;
tgt_text.6665: and without any regard to the plea of age, or the ease of retirement, he shared, and continues to share, with me, the fatigue of public business.
tgt_text.6666: I consider his relations, therefore, as my own;
tgt_text.6667: in which number Nymphi­ dius Lupus, his son, claims my particular regard.
tgt_text.6668: He is a youth of great merit and indefatigable application, and in every respect well worthy of so excellent a father.
tgt_text.6669: The early proof he gave of his merit, when he commanded a regiment of foot, shows him to be equal to any honour you may think proper to confer upon him;
tgt_text.6670: and it gained him the strongest testimony of approbation from those most illustrious personages, Julius Ferox and Fuscus Salinator.
tgt_text.6671: And I will add, Sir, that I shall rejoice in any accession of dignity which he shall receive as an occasion of particular satisfaction to myself.
tgt_text.6672: I BEG your determination, Sir, on a point I am exceed­ ingly doubtful about:
tgt_text.6673: it is whether I should place the public slaves1 as sentries round the prisons of the several cities in this province (as has been hitherto the practice) or employ a party of soldiers for that purpose?
tgt_text.6674: On the one hand, I am afraid the public slaves will not attend this duty with the fidelity they ought;
tgt_text.6675: and on the other, that it will engage too large a body of the soldiery.
tgt_text.6676: In the meanwhile I have joined a few of the latter with the former.
tgt_text.6677: I am appre­ hensive, however, there may be some danger that this method will occasion a general neglect of duty, as it will afford them a mutual opportunity of throwing the blame upon each other.
tgt_text.6678: THERE is no occasion, my dearest Secundus, to draw off any soldiers in order to guard the prisons.
tgt_text.6679: Let us rather persevere in the ancient customs observed in this province, of employing the public slaves for that purpose;
tgt_text.6680: and the fidelity with which they shall execute their duty will depend much upon your care and strict discipline.
tgt_text.6681: It is greatly to be feared, as you observe, if the soldiers should be mixed with the public slaves, they will mutually trust to each other, and by that means grow so much the more negligent.
tgt_text.6682: But my principal objection is that as few soldiers as possible should be withdrawn from their standard.
tgt_text.6683: GABIUS BASSUS, who commands upon the frontiers of Pontica, in a manner suitable to the respect and duty which he owes you, came to me, and has been with me, Sir, for several days.
tgt_text.6684: As far as I could observe, he is a person of great merit and worthy of your favour.
tgt_text.6685: I acquainted him it was your order that he should retain only ten beneficiary1 soldiers, two horse-guards, and one centurion out of the troops which you were pleased to assign to my command.
tgt_text.6686: He assured me those would not be sufficient, and that he would write to you accordingly;
tgt_text.6687: for which reason I thought it proper not immediately to recall his supernumeraries.
tgt_text.6688: I HAVE received from Gabius Bassus the letter you men­ tion, acquainting me that the number of soldiers I had ordered him was not sufficient;
tgt_text.6689: and for your information I have directed my answer to be hereunto annexed.
